pullRequest.body:
Two lemmas for lexicographic order on a`Unique` type are added. 

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

nodes.body:
### PR summary [f2e47f0a3b](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20699/commits/f2e47f0a3b0a1525a429ba07270feec6a9eb44ef)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ MonomialOrder.lex_le_iff_of_unique`
`+ MonomialOrder.lex_lt_iff_of_unique`
`+ lex_le_iff`
`+ lex_le_iff_of_unique`
`+ lex_lt_iff`
`+ lex_lt_iff_of_unique`
`- Finsupp.lex_le_iff`
`- Finsupp.lex_lt_iff`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> Do you expect these to be useful if made simp?

I am not sure. I have no idea, in fact. I tend to prefer the more bundled versions, because mathematically they embody more relevant stuff. For example, I did not tag as simp the two lemmas ahead, MonomialOrder.lex_le_iff and its lt variant.
Do you expect these to be useful if made simp?
Do you expect these to be useful if made simp?
These don't seem unique (pun not intended) to finsupps with codomain ℕ; can you generalize them to general finsupps? You can then reprove these theorems in terms of the more general versions.

I could do, but this stuff on monomial orders requires that the finsupp is WellFounded and this only happens when the codomain is wellfounded. All of this stuff is to be used for polynomials anyway, so I am note sure this is worth the effort here.
I do think "the lexicographic order on 1-tuples is the same as the usual order" is a lemma worth having. And it really shouldn't be any more difficult to prove than the version you give here.
OK, so I'll add that to `Lex`.
It's done. That required to move two lemmas from the MonomialOrder file to the Finsupp.Lex file, and that's an even more appropriate location.
Do you wish that I also add a similar lemma for `Pi.Lex`?
Can this be placed any earlier? It seems like a very basic lemma, and I don't think it should require the `PartialOrder` assumption.

```suggestion
    a < b ↔ ∃ i, (∀ j, j < i → ofLex a j = ofLex b j) ∧ ofLex a i < ofLex b i :=
```

I don't think we should have this; it's just the composition of two other basic theorems, and it's not always the most natural characterization (e.g. if `α` and `N` are linear orders, the negation of `lex_lt_iff` would probably be nicer to work with).

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/Finsupp/MonomialOrder) : lexicographic order on `Unique`

source.title: feat: Lemmas for some monomial orders
